Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 1: History of theatre styles and conventions pre-1945

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 1: History of theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: This unit focuses on the application of acting, direction and design in relation to theatre styles and their conventions pre-1945, that is, from the era up to and including 1944. Students work in production roles with scripts from specific periods that fall between the beginning of theatre history until the end of 1944 focusing on at least two theatre styles, their conventions and histories. They study innovations in theatre production through the styles they explore and apply this knowledge to their interpretations of works.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 1: History of theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: Students develop knowledge and skills about theatre production processes, including dramaturgy, planning, development, and performance to an audience, and they apply this knowledge and skill to their own work. They study safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) working practices in theatre production.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 1: History of theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: Theatre up to and including 1944 encompasses scripts from a wide range of styles including, but not limited to, Agitprop, Ancient Greek, Ancient Roman, Beijing Opera, Bunraku, Commedia Dell 'Arte, Epic Theatre (early works), Elizabethan, Expressionism, Kabuki, Liturgical, Medieval, Miracle plays, Musical theatre, Naturalism, Neoclassical, Noh, Melodrama, Realism, Surrealism, Theatre of Cruelty and Wayang Kulit Theatre.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 1: History of theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: Students begin to develop skills of performance analysis and apply these to the analysis of a play in performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentHeader: Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students explore theatre styles and their conventions pre-1945.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentHeader: Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
Elaboration: They study two or more distinct theatre styles pre-1945 and the conventions and scripts associated with each selected style.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentHeader: Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
Elaboration: Students study developments and innovations in theatre production as they learn about contexts, production roles and performance possibilities for each of the selected theatre styles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentHeader: Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
Elaboration: Through practical workshops, research and dramaturgy, students gain knowledge of how these styles shaped and contributed to the world of theatre pre-1945.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentHeader: Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to identify and describe distinguishing features of two or more theatre styles from pre-1945 and scripts associated with the selected styles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentHeader: Exploring theatre styles and conventions pre-1945
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students focus on the presentation of theatre scripts pre-1945.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They work in at least two production roles to interpret scripts from two or more distinct pre-1945 theatre styles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: Students study and apply relevant conventions of the styles and consider how work in production roles is informed by different theatre styles, their conventions and historical contexts.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They learn about processes for developing characters through acting skills appropriate to the style.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They consider audience culture and the influence of an audience on their work in production roles to enhance the interpretation of scripts.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: Throughout the production process, students will have opportunities to develop oral skills by participating in discussions and explaining how their work in production roles contributes to realising the production aims.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They continue to study and apply elements of theatre composition and safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) working practices in theatre production.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: For Area of Study 2, students must work effectively in at least two production roles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: The production roles for Area of Study 2 are:

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to work effectively in production roles to interpret scripts from two or more pre-1945 theatre styles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students focus on analysing a professional performance of a script.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
Elaboration: They attend a production of a play in performance and study the nature of performance analysis, including analysing audience culture, acting skills, directorial skills, design skills and the ways in which the historical contexts and conventions of theatre styles identified or implied in a script are interpreted in performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
Elaboration: Students study the use of theatre technologies and the elements of theatre composition in a professional theatre performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
Elaboration: Where possible, students should attend and analyse a pre-1945 play in performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to analyse a live professional performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentDescription: interpretation of scripts from pre-1945 through the application of acting, direction and/or design (costume, hair and make-up, props, set, lighting, sound)

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance

ContentDescription: structured questions

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentHeader: Analysing a theatre production in performance
ContentDescription: a research report.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: In this unit, students study contemporary theatre practice through the exploration of scripts from 1945 to the present day. They select scripts from either two distinct theatre styles OR a theatre movement between 1945 and the present day. In either option, students should study at least one Australian play.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: Contemporary theatre movements can be defined as performance styles from 1945 onwards that push the boundaries of traditional theatre styles and conventions. They often consist of a range of conventions and features and can cut across art forms, genres and disciplines.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: This unit focuses on the application of acting, direction and design in relation to contemporary theatre practice from 1945 to the present day. Students work in production roles to interpret scripts. They study developments and innovations in theatre and apply this knowledge to their own work.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: Students develop knowledge of, and skills relating to, theatre production processes that include dramaturgy, planning, development and presentation to an audience, and they apply these to their own work. They study safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable working practices (where possible, using environmentally sustainable approaches) in theatre production. They develop skills in theatre production analysis and evaluation, which they apply to their own work and to the work of other practitioners.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: Examples of theatre styles post-1945 include Kitchen Sink Drama, Immersive theatre, Verbatim theatre, Theatre of the Absurd, Australian realism, Musical theatre, Butoh, Forum theatre.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: Examples of theatre movements post-1945 include Theatre-in-education, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander theatre, Feminist theatre, Post-Colonial theatre, Queer theatre, Black Rights theatre, Theatre for Climate Justice, Physical theatre, Cross-cultural theatre, Post-Dramatic theatre, Memory plays.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentHeader: Unit 2: Contemporary theatre styles and movements
ContentDescription: Note: Some theatre movements may be linked to a particular practitioner or company. Some theatre styles or movements may have been established prior to 1945 and may still have a significant presence post-1945.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students select and explore scripts from contemporary theatre styles and/or movements from 1945 to the present day.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
Elaboration: They study two or more distinct theatre styles OR two or more playwrights within one contemporary theatre movement.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
Elaboration: In examining distinct theatre styles, students consider dramaturgy and research to explore scripts associated with the selected styles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
Elaboration: Similarly, in exploring playwrights and scripts from a contemporary theatre movement, students consider the style(s) and conventions implied in the selected scripts from that movement.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
Elaboration: Dramaturgy may include the social political contexts, cultural origins, intentions, comparisons in structure and languages, production roles and performance possibilities for each of the selected scripts from either the distinct styles OR the selected theatre movement.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
Elaboration: Students learn about audiences and audience culture.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
Elaboration: Through practical workshops and experimentation, students gain knowledge of how these styles and/or movement(s) shape and contribute to the world of contemporary theatre.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to identify and describe the distinguishing features of distinct theatre styles and/or the characteristics of a theatre movement(s) through scripts written from 1945 to the present day.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentHeader: Exploring contemporary theatre styles and/or movements
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students work in at least two of the production roles of actor, director and/or designer to realise scripts from at least two distinct contemporary theatre styles or one contemporary theatre movement from 1945 to the present day.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: Through this work, students gain an understanding of how production teams can work collaboratively to interpret scripts.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They also learn how work in production roles is informed by, and contributes to, the development of different theatre styles and/or a theatre movement.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They consider ways in which theatre production work is itself shaped by the styles and contexts inherent in scripts and theatre movements.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: Students continue to learn about theatre production processes, including dramaturgy, planning, development, performance to audiences, and audience culture, and they apply this knowledge to their own work.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: Throughout the production processes, students will have opportunities to develop oral skills by participating in discussions and explaining how their work in production roles contributes to realising the production aims.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
Elaboration: They study and apply elements of theatre composition and safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) working practices in theatre production.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to work in production roles to interpret scripts from theatre styles or movements from 1945 to the present day.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting scripts
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students attend a performance and focus on analysing and evaluating a professional theatre production of a script.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
Elaboration: They study the nature of theatre production analysis and evaluation, including the application of acting, direction and design and their effect on an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
Elaboration: Students study the use of theatre technologies and elements of theatre composition in professional theatre performance, and they study the relationship between contexts of the script and the use of production roles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
Elaboration: Where possible, for this area of study students should attend and analyse a play in performance from the period of 1945 to the present day.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to analyse and evaluate a theatre production.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production

ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentDescription: interpretation of scripts from contemporary theatre styles or movements from 1945 to the present day through the application of acting, direction and/or design (costume, hair and make-up, props, set, lighting, sound)

ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentDescription: an analytical essay.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentHeader: Analysing and evaluating a theatre production
ContentDescription: At least one assessment task must be practice-based, at least one task must be written, and at least one task must include an oral component.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: In this unit, students develop an interpretation of a script through the three stages of the theatre production process: planning, development and presentation. Students specialise in two production roles, working collaboratively to interpret and realise the production of a script. They apply the knowledge developed during this process to analyse and evaluate how production roles can be used to interpret script excerpts previously unstudied. Students develop knowledge of elements of theatre composition and safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) working practices in the theatre.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Students attend a performance selected from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist and analyse and evaluate the interpretation of the script of the performance. The playlist is published annually on the VCAA website.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: For Area of Study 1, students select two production roles from the following list:

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Actor

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Director

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Designer - any one or two of costume, hair and make-up, props, set, lighting, sound.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: For Area of Study 1, more than one student may specialise in each production role and schools may decide to focus only on specific production roles. These decisions will be influenced by the script selected for interpretation and/or the size of the class and/or the available resources.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Across Unit 3, students engage with at least three scripts. For Area of Study 1, schools select a script for interpretation in a performance to an audience and for Area of Study 2, excerpts from a previously unstudied script are selected for analysis. For Area of Study 3, students must read and study the script for the production they attend and then analyse and evaluate the performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: The production for Area of Study 3 must be selected from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist published annually by the VCAA.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students focus on developing skills that can be applied to the interpretation of a script for performance to an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
Elaboration: They work collaboratively to contribute to the development of a production of a selected script.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
Elaboration: As members of the production team, students undertake exercises and tasks throughout the three stages of the production process, leading to a performance of the selected script to an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
ContentDescription: Students apply dramaturgy and consider how the script’s context, styles and intended meaning can be used to inform their interpretation and any possible recontextualisations of a script for an audience, and they consider audience culture.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
Elaboration: Students experiment and apply elements of theatre composition in order to manipulate meaning for an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
ContentDescription: Students develop an understanding of, and enhance their skills in, working in two production roles across all stages of the production process.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
Elaboration: They apply dramaturgy in the work they undertake in the two production roles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
Elaboration: They develop skills that contribute to theatre production processes, including working collaboratively, time management, planning, scheduling, evaluating and reflecting.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
ContentDescription: Throughout the production process, students develop their oral skills through discussions with others in the production team or through explaining how their work in production roles contributes to realising the production aims.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
Elaboration: They further develop knowledge of and apply safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) working practices in theatre production.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to interpret a script across the stages of the production process through collaborative work undertaken in two production roles.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Staging theatre
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students interpret the theatrical possibilities of excerpts from a script.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
Elaboration: In doing so, they demonstrate their understanding of working in two production roles across the three stages of the production process.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
Elaboration: Students respond to and interpret script excerpts and stimulus material, formulating and justifying interpretative possibilities, including recontextualisation, and they document their interpretation.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
Elaboration: The documentation should include written material, annotated script excerpts and illustrations, as appropriate, to support interpretive choices.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
ContentDescription: Students revisit their learning about the stages of the production process, their learning about dramaturgy, and ways in which their work in production roles can contribute to interpretations of scripts for performance to audiences.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
Elaboration: They develop their understanding of audiences and audience culture.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
ContentDescription: They further develop their understanding of safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) theatre work practices.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
ContentDescription: The script excerpts used for teaching and learning and assessment in this area of study must be different from scripts studied for Areas of Study 1 and 3.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to outline concepts and ideas for an interpretation of excerpts from a script and explain how these could be realised in a theatre production.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a script
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students attend, analyse and evaluate an interpretation of a script in a production from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
Elaboration: Students analyse and evaluate the relationship between the written script and its interpretation on stage.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
Elaboration: In doing so, students study ways in which the interpretation on stage draws on and interprets the contexts in the script as well as any recontextualisation choices.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
Elaboration: This includes the decisions that have been made when interpreting the script, for example decisions about acting, direction and design, and the use of theatre technologies and elements of theatre composition.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
ContentDescription: Students evaluate the ways in which theatre practitioners (such as the director, actors, designers) and dramaturgical processes have contributed to the interpretation on stage.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
Elaboration: Students study how the theatre styles and contexts implied in the written script are interpreted when the play is performed to an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
Elaboration: Students attend the theatre production and develop skills in applying relevant theatre terminology to analyse and evaluate how the script has been interpreted.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
Elaboration: Their analysis and evaluation of the production is informed by work undertaken in Areas of Study 1 and 2.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to analyse and evaluate the interpretation of a written script from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist in production to an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating theatre
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: In this unit, students study a scene and an associated monologue from a script. They initially develop an interpretation of the prescribed scene. This work includes exploring theatrical possibilities and using dramaturgy across the three stages of the production process. Students then develop an interpretation of the monologue that is embedded in the specified scene. To realise their interpretation, students work in production roles as an actor and director, or as a designer.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Students' work for Areas of Study 1 and 2 is supported through the analysis and evaluation of a production they attend for their work in Area of Study 3. The production must be selected from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist and must be different from the production they analyse in Unit 3. The playlist is published annually on the VCAA website. Students analyse and evaluate acting, direction and design in the selected production and consider the application of theatre technologies.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: In conducting their work in Areas of Study 1 and 2, students further develop their knowledge and application of inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) theatre practices.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: For Areas of Study 1 and 2, students must select a script, scene and monologue from the VCE Theatre Studies monologue examination published annually by the VCAA. The list will consist of a set of prescribed scripts, a specified scene from each script and a selected monologue from that scene.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: In this unit, the term 'scene' refers to the designated segment(s) or excerpt(s) of a script selected from the VCE Theatre Studies monologue examination. Some prescribed monologues may be drawn from more than one scene across the script.

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: In Unit 4 Areas of Study 1 and 2, the production roles are:

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Actor and director - students must work in both roles

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: OR

Subject: Theatre Studies
ContentDescription: Designer - any two of costume, hair and make-up, props, set, lighting, sound.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students document and report on dramaturgical decisions that could inform an interpretation of a monologue and its prescribed scene.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentDescription: Students conduct dramaturgy as the basis for decisions that will inform their interpretation.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
Elaboration: This includes research into the contexts of the script, influences on the playwright(s), the world of the audience, and possible recontextualisations.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentDescription: Students then outline an interpretation of the scene, focusing on the ways in which the scene could be approached as a piece of theatre, including its place within the script, its specific structure, its characters, its themes, its images and ideas, its theatrical possibilities and its theatre style(s).

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentDescription: Students consider how elements of theatre composition and theatre technologies could be applied to realise their proposed interpretative concepts and aims.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
Elaboration: They identify issues relating to safe, ethical, inclusive and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) theatre practices that they will need to apply in their work to realise their proposed interpretation.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to describe and justify an interpretation of a monologue and its prescribed scene within the world of the play.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentHeader: Dramaturgical research and presenting theatrical possibilities
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students focus on the interpretation of a monologue from a scene contained within a script selected from the VCE Theatre Studies monologue examination published annually in Term 2 on the VCAA website.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
ContentDescription: Students select a monologue from the current examination and study the text of the monologue, the prescribed scene in which it is embedded and the complete script from which the scene is derived.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
Elaboration: Students apply selected production roles and develop an interpretation of the monologue that is informed by their study of the prescribed scene and the complete script.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
Elaboration: Their interpretation is informed by dramaturgy they conduct, including the contexts of the play and its intended meanings.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
Elaboration: Students make decisions about how the contexts, theatrical possibilities, elements of theatre composition and theatre styles will inform their interpretation of the monologue.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
Elaboration: Students work in their selected production roles to realise and present their interpretation of the monologue.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
Elaboration: They consider the interrelationships between acting, direction and design areas.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
Elaboration: They consider safe, ethical and sustainable (where possible, environmentally sustainable) theatre practices.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to interpret and present a monologue through the application of two production roles and orally justify and explain their interpretative decisions.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interpreting a monologue
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students focus on the analysis and evaluation of the acting, direction and design in a performance of a production selected from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: Students attend a production selected from the playlist.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: They study the theatre style(s) evident in the performance and analyse and evaluate how actor(s), director(s) and designer(s) interpret the script for an audience.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: They consider the interrelationships between acting, direction and design in the performance.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: In doing so, students consider character(s) in the play, how the actor(s) interpreted them on stage and the contribution of the director(s) and designer(s) to the interpretation and intended meaning(s).

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: They study acting skills used by the actor(s) to portray character(s) to convey the intended meanings of the play and the establishment, maintenance and/or manipulation of the actor–audience relationship.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: Students’ understanding of the techniques being used by the actor(s), director(s) and designer(s) is informed by techniques they used to interpret the monologue they selected for Area of Study 1.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: They refine their understanding of the terminology associated with analysing and evaluating theatre performances.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, students should be able to analyse and evaluate acting, direction and design in a performance of a production from the prescribed VCE Theatre Studies Playlist.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, students will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: Students will interpret a monologue from a scene in a play and explain their interpretive decisions.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: The monologue will be selected from the VCE Theatre Studies monologue examination set annually by the VCAA.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: A panel appointed by the VCAA will set the examination.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: All key knowledge and key skills that underpin Unit 4 Outcomes 1 and 2 are examinable.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: Assessors appointed by the VCAA will mark the examination.

Subject: Theatre Studies
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: VCAA examination rules will apply.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: Details of these rules are published annually in the VCE Administrative Handbook and in the VCE monologue examination specifications.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: The performance venue is set annually by the VCAA.

ContentDescription: The duration of the examination will be no more than 8 minutes.

ContentDescription: A panel appointed by the VCAA will set the examination.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
Elaboration: All key knowledge and key skills that underpin Unit 3 Outcomes 1, 2 and 3 and Unit 4 Outcomes 1 and 3 are examinable.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Analysing and evaluating a performance
ContentDescription: Duration: one-and-a-half hours.
